places.name: Southampton
places.summary: Embarkation point for the invasion. Stayed in a camp in the woods awaiting D-Day, the camp was sealed on May 27th preventing any further leave.

places.name: Southend
places.summary: Pre-invasion station where Edgar spent five months. Made friends with Mrs Woodlands and hoped to have Winnie visit before deployment.

places.name: Middleton
places.summary: Edgar's home town. The bells of Crepon Church reminded him of those at Middleton. Home to Winnie and his family.

places.name: Crepon
places.summary: First gun position after D-Day landing. Defended the beach head with AA guns against heavy night raids. Visited the church and village cinema during rest periods.

places.name: Le Hamel
places.summary: Small village near the landing beach, badly damaged during the assault. One of the villages that 'caught the full blast' of D-Day.

places.name: Bayeux
places.summary: First visit on July 17th. Found the cathedral beautiful but the town had narrow streets and unpleasant smells. Bought red butter and cheese at 400 francs.

places.name: Caen
places.summary: Major bombing target. Witnessed over 500 Lancasters and Halifaxes bomb the city on July 8th. A recreation shed was salvaged from a site near Caen.

places.name: Arromanches
places.summary: Beach unloading work helping with the Mulberry harbour operations. Enjoyed swimming at the same beach where they landed on D-Day. Saw graves of fallen soldiers.

places.name: Creully
places.summary: About 5 miles from Crepon. Visited for the first ENSA show in France. Had coffee in a fly-filled cafe and bought butter from a local farm.

places.name: Falaise
places.summary: Passed through on the 200-mile journey from Crepon. 'Very badly knocked about' - one heap of rubble from Allied bombing.

places.name: Argentan
places.summary: Route marker on the journey from Normandy to Amiens. Part of the 200-mile convoy move.

places.name: L'Aigle
places.summary: Route marker on the journey to Amiens. The people further inland were 'very pleased to see the British' compared to the dour Normandy folk.

places.name: Amiens
places.summary: Gun position on high chalky ground with the beautiful cathedral as a landmark. Had a night out enjoying cafes with accordion music. FFI rounding up snipers in the woods.

places.name: Boulogne
places.summary: Stationed 2 miles from the devastated city. 'Never have I seen such places so badly bombed.' Buried a German officer and Canadian soldier. Could see the White Cliffs of Dover.

places.name: Calais
places.summary: Watched Lancasters and Halifaxes bombing Calais from Boulogne with no opposition. Could see across to England's White Cliffs.

places.name: Desvres
places.summary: Out of bounds industrial town 10 miles away. Met George Ruffin, a friendly cycle shop owner who had saved whisky since 1940 for English soldiers.

places.name: Bruges
places.summary: Arrived on Edgar's birthday in terrible weather. A big city with plenty in the shops. Went to pictures to see 'Alloah' and explored the city with Alec.

places.name: Knokke
places.summary: Port where Germans held out. Guns used for ground shooting as field artillery, firing over 200 rounds to destroy German positions and ammo dumps.

places.name: Brussels
places.summary: 48-hour leave stay at the Albert Hotel. Took a conducted tour of the city. Air raid warnings from V-1 flying bombs but all clear soon followed.

places.name: Louvain
places.summary: Transit camp in schools awaiting posting to Berlin. Pleasant walks, cinema visits, and befriended a jolly 60-year-old Belgian caretaker. Watched civilians dance to 'Tipperary'.

places.name: Antwerp
places.summary: Gun graveyard on an aerodrome where hundreds of 3.7 and Bofors guns were greased for storage. Enjoyed swimming baths and witnessed VE Day celebrations.

places.name: Kapelle
places.summary: 8 miles from Antwerp. Witnessed VE Day here - sirens sounded after midnight. Saw civilians ransacking collaborators' houses on May 13th.

places.name: Nieuport
places.summary: Firing camp 10 miles from Ostende. Stationed in a big school with wooden beds. Guns put into action for practice before 'Cease Firing' order came through.

places.name: Namur
places.summary: Brief stop at an American camp before being redirected to Louvain. Part of the usual army mix-up.

places.name: Goes
places.summary: Rest stop to brew tea and eat biscuits and corned beef on the journey to Zuid Beveland.

places.name: Zuid Beveland
places.summary: Gun position on a dyke in front of the sea. Very bleak and cold. Slept in a big granary vacated by Germans. Buried an unknown artillery man washed up on shore.

places.name: Middelburg
places.summary: Had a photograph taken here in new kit, which was sent home to Winnie.

places.name: Wesel
places.summary: Crossed the Rhine here on a Royal Engineers bridge. 'A heap of rubble' - saw great locomotives tipped on end and burnt out railway carriages.

places.name: Munster
places.summary: Passed through on route to Berlin. Like Wesel, 'a heap of rubble' from Allied bombing. Buildings a mass of twisted metal and steel.

places.name: Bielefeld
places.summary: Stayed two nights in German barracks, sleeping on the floor. Fleas in the rooms made it unpleasant.

places.name: Brunswick
places.summary: Stayed about a week in German barracks. Built outdoor cooking places of bricks and mud while other regiments practiced for the march past Berlin.

places.name: Hanover
places.summary: Transit point on the journey to and from Berlin. Passed through multiple times during movements.

places.name: Berlin
places.summary: Final posting. Billeted in a house with flats and the best bed in his army career. Visited the Olympic Stadium. City in ruins - 'smelt the whiff of dead people buried in the rubble.'

places.name: Dover
places.summary: Port of return to England. Final leg of the journey home after demobilization from Berlin.
